Graphical abstract The CO2 cycloaddition of photothermally-driven. Solar energy is considered as the cleanest, cheapest, and most sustainable energy source, and CO2 cycloaddition that is drove by solar energy has unique advantages in the aspect of energy and environmental. Therefore, Zn and N co-doped porous carbon nanosheets (ZNCs), which were synthesized by a simple one-step pyrolysis method, as catalysts and photothermal material to photothermally drive cycloaddition of CO2. The prepared ZNCs show graphene-like layered structure, uniformly distributed Lewis acid (Zn atoms) sites and Lewis base (N atoms) sites, full spectrum absorption and high photothermal conversion efficiency. More importantly, ZNCs have a higher catalytic efficiency than traditional heating methods because it can be quickly in-situ heated by light, hence the yield of cyclic carbonate reached 91.1% (0.1 MPa CO2, 1000 mW·cm−2 full-spectrum irradiation, 12 h). ZNCs were recycled five times without significant reduction in catalytic efficiency, and have high activity to other series of epoxides. A possible CO2 cycloaddition mechanism which is catalyzed by ZNCs is proposed, including the step of adsorption, ring opening, insertion and cyclic carbonates formation. Keywords CO2 cycloaddition Photothermal conversion efficiency Zn and N co-doped porous carbon Photothermal catalysis Heterogeneous catalysis 1 Introduction The rapid development of industry and the large-scale combustion of fossil fuels have gradually increased the discharge of CO2, and brought a series of environmental problems such as greenhouse effect and acidification of seawater [1,2]. Carbon capture utilization and storage are important means to solve the above problems [3]. However, due to the high cost and uncertainty of long-term geological storage, more attention is focused on carbon utilization. The research and development of CO2 fixation and chemical conversion are of great significance no matter from the perspective of resource utilization, or environment and cost [4]. Thereinto, the cycloaddition of CO2 with epoxides to prepare cyclic carbonates has advantages of high atoms utilization and less by-products [5,6]. Moreover, the cyclic carbonates, as an important high-value chemicals, can be used as aprotic solvents, electrolytes for lithium-ion batteries, and intermediates for organic synthesis [7-9]. However, CO2 has high thermodynamic stability and kinetic inertness [10], therefore, a variety of homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysts have been reported by researchers in traditional heating method, such as ionic liquids [11], organic bases [12], metal complexes [13], metal organic framework [14], polymeric ionic liquids [15] and porous organic polymers [16]. Meanwhile, the cycloaddition mechanism of CO2 with epoxide has been conducted in-depth researched and proposed: CO2 is activated on the alkaline substrates, and epoxide is ring-opened by nucleophilic reagents after being activated by Lewis acid or hydrogen bond donors, and the catalytic efficiency is improved by Lewis acid-base synergistic effect [17-20]. But there are also some defects such as the conversion of CO2 often needs high temperature and pressure in traditional heating method. Based on energy, environment and cost, the cycloaddition of CO2 under mild conditions is very attractive. Therefore, using clean and cheap solar energy to drive cycloaddition of CO2 into high-value chemicals will be a very perfect choice [21]. Since the discovery of the photoinduced reduction of CO2 on semiconductors [22], a large number of researchers have devoted to the work of converting CO2 into carbon monoxide, methane, methanol, formic acid, ethanol and other energy chemicals through solar-driven methods [23-25]. However, there are few researches on the cycloaddition of CO2 with epoxide by light interference. Yang et al.[26] prepared a MOFs-derived hollow N-doped porous carbon catalyst (HPC-800) with a high concentration of single Zn atoms, and HPC-800 was used to catalyze CO2 cycloaddition through the photothermal effect, and the yield of cyclic carbonate reached 94% after 10 h irradiation at 0.1 MPa. However, the preparation method of HPC-800 is complicated, and the relationship between photothermal effect and catalytic performance was not studied in detail. Sharma et al.[27] studied the effect of visible light on the cycloaddition of CO2 with epoxide. Under the 30 × 3 W intensity LED lamp, the temperature of catalytic system rose to 57 °C after cycloaddition, and the yield of the cyclic carbonate was the same as the result of traditional heating to 57 °C. It is same as the conclusion of Guo et al.[28,29]. Based on the above considerations, the catalysts with abundant catalytic active sites and excellent photothermal conversion performance are important for cycloaddition that is drove by photothermal effect. In the aspect of photothermal effect, heterogeneous carbon-based materials have excellent light absorption capacity and high photothermal conversion efficiency in the full spectrum range, and have been widely used in the fields of seawater evaporation and photothermal therapy [30-32]. Moreover, in the aspect of catalysis, carbon-based materials also have advantages of wide range of sources, low cost, stable chemical properties, easy control of chemical structure and surface functional groups, etc., and have been widely used as effective catalysts or catalyst carriers [33-35]. The characteristics of carbon-based materials show their great application potential in photothermally-driven catalytic reactions. In this study, biomass raw material glucose was used as a carbon source, zinc nitrate hexahydrate was used as a Zn source, melamine was used as a N source and sacrificial template, and a simple one-step pyrolysis method was used to synthesize ZNCs. Whereafter, ZNCs were used as photothermal conversion materials, and doped Zn and N atoms were respectively used as Lewis acid-base catalytic active sites, to photothermally-driven CO2 cycloaddition with tetrabutylammonium bromide (TBAB) as a co-catalyst under mild conditions. More importantly, the influence of photothermal effect on catalytic performance is discussed in detail. This work not only provided a simple photothermally-driven CO2 cycloaddition strategy, but also explained the relationship between photothermal effect and catalytic efficiency. The result provided a certain reference for the general photothermally-driven catalytic reaction in catalyst design and energy conversion. 2 Experimental 2.1 Chemicals Melamine (99%), glucose (AR), chloroform-d (CDCl3) (D, 99.8%), TBAB (99%), propylene oxide (99%), epichlorohydrin (98%), 1,2-butylene oxide (greater than99%), styrene oxide (98%), glycidol (96%), cyclohexene oxide (98%), Isobutylene oxide (97%), Benzyl glycidyl ether (≥97.0%), activated carbon (AC, powder) and Butyl glycidyl ether (≥98.0%) were purchased from Aladdin Industrial Inc. (Shanghai, China). Zinc nitrate hexahydrate (99%) was obtained from Xilong Scientific Co., Ltd. (Sichuan, China). CO2 (99.99%) was purchased from Kunming Guangruida Gas Co., Ltd. (Yunnan, China). All reagents were analytically pure and can be used without further purification unless otherwise noted. 2.2 Synthesis of ZNCs The ZNCs were obtained by a typical preparation procedure, 0.36 g zinc nitrate hexahydrate, 2.16 g glucose, and 30 g melamine (molar ratio:1/10/200) were added into 150 mL of anhydrous ethanol. The mixture was continuously stirred for 12 h to make it uniforml dispersion, and then a white solid was obtained after the mixture was heated to 80 °C with stirring. Subsequently, the white solid was further dried in 80 °C vacuum and grounded into powder. Finally, the dried powder was put into a crucible with cover and was heated in two-step under nitrogen protection: 1, the dried powder was heaetd to 550 °C at the rate of 2 °C·min−1 and kept for 1 h; 2, the dried powder was heated to desired temperatures (700–1000 ℃) at the rate of 5 °C·min−1 and kept for 1 h. In order to distinguish products in different preparation condition, the ZNCs were synthesized under different temperatures at 700, 800, 900 and 1000 ℃ were denoted as ZNC-700, ZNC-800, ZNC-900, ZNC-1000, respectively. The sample obtained from the first phase of pyrolysis was named ZNC-550. The sample with the molar ratio of zinc nitrate hexahydrate, glucose and melamine of 1/20/200 and 1/5/200 was named ZNC-8000.5 and ZNC-8002, respectively. The N-doped porous carbon nanosheet, prepared without Zn source, was named NC-800. 2.3 Characterization Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) analyses were performed with Cu-Kα radiation under 40 KV and 36 mA and the test range is 10–80° (D-MAX2500/PC, Japan). Raman spectra were detected with a 325 nm excitation laser (Renishaw UK). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was taken by an AXIS Ultra DLD instrument with Al-Kα radiation as the monochromatic source (KRATOS, Japan). Specific surface area, pore size and pore volume were measured on a NOVA 4200e instrument using N2 adsorption/desorption at 77.35 K and the samples were outgassed at 280 ℃ for 4 h under vacuum before measurement (Quantachrome, USA). The morphologies characteristics of samples were investigated using a scanning electron microscope (SEM, NANOSEM-450, America), and its compositions and element distribution was obtained with an EDX elemental mapping attached to the SEM. A high-resolution transmission electron microscope (HRTEM) was recorded on a Tecnai G2 F20 instrument. The high-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) measurements were taken on a FEI Themis Z. 1H Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) spectrum were recorded in the 600 MHz Bruker Advance III HD spectrometer (Bruker BioSpin, Switzerland) using CDCl3 as the solvent. Ultraviolet–visible-near-infrared (UV–Vis-NIR) spectrophotometer (UV-3600, Japan) were used to study absorption powders and the test range of the spectrum is 200–2500 nm. Full-spectrum Xe lamp (CEL-HXF300, China) was used as the light source for CO2 cycloaddition. Thermal imaging camera (FLIR ONE PRO) was used to measure the surface temperature of the samples. The ICP-MS (Thermo Fisher Icap-7400) was utilized to calculate the amount of metal in the samples. The acidity and basicity properties were measured by a temperature program desorption (TPD, AutoChem1 II 2920). 2.4 Characterization of catalytic performance The photothermally-driven catalytic performance was researched in a photoreactor with quartz glass on top. In a typical experiment, 20 mmol epoxide, 20 mg ZNCs, and 0.1 mmol TBAB were placed into photoreactor and stirred. CO2 was fed into the photoreactor and sequentially discharged several times to remove other gases in the photoreactor, the reaction pressure was kept at 0.1 MPa. The cycloaddition of CO2 was carried out at room temperature with a full-spectrum Xe lamp irradiation for 2–12 h and the light intensity was maintained at 1000 mW·cm−2. After the reaction, the temperature of the reactor naturally dropped to room temperature, and then the photoreactor is further cooled to below 10 ℃ to prevent volatilization of unreacted PO, and finally the reaction mixture was filtered and collected. The product was detected by 1H NMR spectrum, and the yield of cyclic carbonate was calculated by peak integration method as previously reported [36-38]. In the reusability studies, the catalyst was filtered and washed with ethanol after each reaction, and then the catalyst dried at 80 °C for the next experiment. 2.5 Evaluation of photothermal conversion efficiency A lab-made evaluation system of photothermal conversion efficiency is illustrated as Fig.S1. 3.5 mL catalyst dispersion of a certain mass fraction was placed in a 4 mL cuvette (1 × 1 × 4 cm) and sealed, then a thermocouple was inserted into the cuvette to detect the temperature of the dispersion. Put the cuvette into a polystyrene foam that was cut out an area of 1 × 1 cm as light receiving area before being sealed by tin foil, so that the heat dissipation could be avoided by polystyrene foam and tin foil. The position of the cuvette was adjusted in order to receive the light intensity of 100 mW·cm−2. The measurement steps were as follows: the dispersion begins to heat up under the irradiation of Xe lamp, and the temperature gradually balanced and reached the maximum value. At the same time, the heat absorption was equaled to the heat dissipation of the dispersion, and then the Xe lamp was turned off to make it natural cool down for 1 h. The accuracy of the thermocouple is ± 0.1 ℃. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of the catalysts The sacrificial template method is a simple and versatile way to prepare two-dimensional or porous materials [39,40]. The layered graphite carbon nitride (g-C3N4) can be formed by pyrolysis and condensation of melamine at 550 ℃ (Fig.S2), and the structure of g-C3N4 is destroyed and gradually decomposed when temperature exceeds 700 ℃[41]. A simple one-pot pyrolysis method was used to synthesize ZNCs with glucose as a carbon source, zinc nitrate hexahydrate as a zinc source, melamine as a nitrogen source and sacrificial template, as schematically depicted in Scheme 1 . In the process of pyrolysis, the glucose-derived aromatic intermediate is confined to the g-C3N4 interlayer gap at 550 °C through the cooperative condensation process. Since the g-C3N4 template decomposes when the temperature exceeds 700 ℃, and ZNCs are released at higher temperature. In the whole process, the part of the nitrogen element in the g-C3N4 template and the added zinc element are co-doped into the porous carbon nanosheets [42]. The XRD patterns show the structural changes of ZNC-550 and ZNCs, as shown in Fig. 1 (a). The two obvious diffraction peaks of ZNC-550, which are located at 13.1° and 27.4°, are attributed to the (001) and (002) crystal planes of g-C3N4, respectively, the result proved that the main component of ZNC-550 is g-C3N4 [43,44]. ZNCs calcined at 700–1000 ℃ have obvious diffraction peaks around 25° which belong to the (002) crystal plane of graphite. Notably, the (002) crystal plane of ZNCs shifts from 25.9° to 24.6°, and the intensity of diffraction peaks are also weakened because the layer accumulation of ZNCs is decreased while more N atoms are inserted into the carbon lattice with the temperature increasing, which indicated that the crystallinity and disordered structure of ZNCs are reduced and increased, respectively [45]. The Raman spectra of ZNCs show two characteristic peaks of typical carbon materials at 1325 cm−1 and 1570 cm−1, namely the D band and the G band [46,47], which represent sp2-hybridized graphitized carbon and sp3-hybridized carbon with edge defects in carbon materials, respectively [48], as shown in Fig. 1(b). The defects and graphitization degree of carbon materials can be judged according to the ratio (ID/IG) of the peak intensity of the D band and the G band, and higher ID/IG value reflects more defective carbon structure. As shown in Fig. 1(b), the ID/IG value of ZNCs increases first and then decreases with the calcination temperature increasing, presumably because a lot of defects are created by the decomposition of g-C3N4; however, with the calcination temperature further increasing, the N atoms of edge defects is inserted into the carbon lattice to increase the graphitization degree [49]. For all spectra, the intensity of the D band is greater than G-band, it indicated that a large number of defects are caused by doping N into the carbon materials [50]. The defects can introduce more active sites and improved the catalytic activity of ZNCs to catalyze the CO2 cycloaddition [51-53]. FT-IR spectra was used to further clarify the structure of ZNC-550 and ZNCs. It can be seen from the Fig. 1(c) that the characteristic peaks at 1568 cm−1 and 1242 cm−1 are C = N and C-N bond stretching vibrations, and the peak at 421 cm−1 is the Zn-N peak [54,55]. This indicates that Zn atoms mainly exist in the form of Zn-N bonds in the samples. The acidity and basicity properties of ZNC-800 were measured by a temperature program desorption (TPD) technique using NH3 (NH3-TPD) and CO2 (CO2-TPD) as probe gas, and the results are shown in Fig. 1(d), the result directly proves the existence of Lewis acid (Zn atoms) and Lewis base (N atoms) sites in ZNC-800. By calculation, the acid/basic concentrations of ZNC-800 are 0.222 cm3·g−1 and 482 cm3·g−1, respectively [56]. The specific surface area and pore structure of ZNC-550 and ZNCs were determined by N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms (Fig. 2 (a)). Notably, ZNCs belong to the typical type IV isotherms, as well as show obvious absorption and small hysteresis loops in the relatively high range of P/P0 (0.4–1.0), but the adsorption capacity of ZNC-550 is very small [57], the results indicated that there are abundant mesopores in ZNC-700, ZNC-800, ZNC-900 and ZNC-1000, and few pores in ZNC-550[58], that can be further verified by the pore size distribution diagram in Fig. 2(b). The specific surface area and porous properties of ZNC-550 and ZNCs are summarized in Table 1 . The BET specific surface areas of ZNC-550, ZNC-700, ZNC-800, ZNC-900 and ZNC-1000 were calculated to be 14.71, 151.27, 315.91, 373.73 and 313.87 m2·g−1, respectively; and the total pore volumes of ZNC-550, ZNC-700, ZNC-800, ZNC-900 and ZNC-1000 were calculated to be 0.079, 0.585, 1.271, 1.224 and 1.223 cm3·g−1, respectively. The specific surface area and total pore volume of the ZNC-550 is relatively small, and there is basically no pore structure. With pyrolysis temperature increasing, the generated g-C3N4 gradually decomposes and forms a large number of void structures, and the specific surface area and total pore volume also gradually increase. The specific surface area of ZNC-900 reached the maximum 373.73 m2·g−1. When the temperature further increasing to 1000 ℃, the specific surface area and total pore volume decreased due to the increase of graphitization degree and the decrease of defects. A large specific surface area can provide more active sites and rich void structure to facilitate the adsorption of CO2 and epoxide, which is beneficial to CO2 cycloaddition [59,60]. The content of Zn in ZNC-550 and ZNCs was determined by ICP-MS, and the results are shown in Table S1. The results show that the Zn contents of ZNC-550, ZNC-700, ZNC-800, ZNC-900 and ZNC-1000 were 0.68 %, 0.85 %, 1.13 %, 0.29% and 0.11 %, respectively. The reason why the lower Zn content of ZNC-550 and ZNC-700 is that the g-C3N4 is not completely decomposed, which increased the total mass of the obtained samples. When the temperature reached 800 ℃, g-C3N4 is completely decomposed, the total mass of the obtained ZNC-800 was reduced, and the Zn content reached a maximum of 1.13% at this time. When the temperature reached 900 ℃ and 1000 ℃, about 74.3% and 90.3% Zn atoms are carbothermal reduced and then evaporated, respectively [61]. In order to investigate the morphology and microstructure of ZNCs, the product ZNC-800 was selected and analyzed by SEM and TEM. As shown in Fig. 3 (a,b), the SEM images of ZNC-800 show a graphene-like ultra-thin layered structure and wrinkled nanosheets morphology, and have typical porous characteristic. The TEM images further show the wrinkled nanosheets structure, as shown in Fig. 3(c,d), because carbon material grows on g-C3N4 nanosheets before exfoliating at high temperature. The wrinkled nanosheets and porous structure not only are conducive to expose more active sites, but also can receive more light and enhance light utilization. A representative area was selected (Fig. 3(b)) and scanned the element mapping images as shown in Fig. 3(e-h), the results confirmed that C, O, N, and Zn elements are uniformly distributed in the entire sample. Moreover, a HAADF-STEM image shows that the single Zn atoms (bright dots marked with red cycles) are uniformly distributed on the entire carbon material, which will improve atoms utilization [33]. XPS spectra was used to further determine the surface characteristics and chemical composition of ZNC-800. As shown in Fig. 4 (a), the signals of the elements C, N, O and Zn are displayed. It further proved that Zn and N elements are doped into porous carbon nanosheets. The peak with a binding energy of 284.8 eV, which is observed from the high-resolution C1s spectrum in Fig. 4(b), is generally considered to be sp2-hybridized graphitic carbon [62]. The other peaks at higher band energies can be considered as oxygen-containing and nitrogen-containing groups on ZNC-800, and the peaks with binding energies of 285.6, 286.5 and 288.0 eV can be attributed to C-N, C-O, C = O/C = N, respectively [63,64]. The high-resolution spectrum of N1s fitted in Fig. 4(c) shows four peaks at 398.3, 399.2, 400.6 and 401.7 eV, which can be attributed to pyridine-N, Zn-Nx, pyrrole-N and graphite-N, respectively [65-67]. Among them, the proportion of pyridine-N reaches 52.93%, and previous studies have shown that pyridine-N not only has a certain adsorption effect on CO2, but also acts as a nucleophile to attack the epoxide and promote the cycloaddition [68]. The proportion of Zn-Nx reached 17.57%, and previous studies have shown that Zn-Nx may be the catalytically active site for CO2 cycloaddition [29,69]. In addition, the Zn2p XPS spectrum in Fig. 4(d) shows that Zn elements in ZNC-800 exhibit two valence states of Zn0 and Zn2+ with the binding energies located at 1046.6 and 1023.8 eV for Zn0 and 1044.9, 1022.0 eV for Zn2+ , respectively. It is because a small part of Zn2+ are carbothermal reduced to Zn0 under high temperature conditions [61]. 3.2 Characterization of the photothermal performance To achieve the photothermally-driven catalytic reaction, the catalysts should not only have abundant catalytic active sites, but also have the ability to convert light energy into heat energy. The prerequisite for realizing photothermal conversion is that catalysts should have broad-spectrum absorption and high light absorption. Therefore, the characteristic of absorption capacity of the catalysts in the UV–Vis-NIR spectrum is extremely important for studying its photothermally-driven catalytic performance. The UV–Vis-NIR absorption spectra of ZNC-550 and ZNCs are shown in Fig. 5 (a). It can be seen that ZNC-550 shows a good spectral absorption in the ultraviolet region, but the spectral absorption of visible and near-infrared is significantly reduced. The absorption capacity of ZNC-700 in the visible-near infrared region is greatly enhanced, because g-C3N4 gradually decomposes with the calcine temperature increasing. ZNC-800, ZNC-900 and ZNC-1000 show excellent absorption capacity in the full spectrum range (200–2500 nm). This is because g-C3N4 completely decomposes and releases porous carbon nanosheets. The full spectrum absorption capacity of the carbon material is enhanced by both the surface area and the porous structure. The photothermal conversion efficiency (PCE) is considered as a main parameter to evaluate the photothermal conversion performance of a certain material. PCE of ZNC-550 and ZNCs were tested through the heating and cooling curve of dispersion. Initially, the heating and cooling curves of ZNC-800 dispersion with different mass fractions were investigated under simulated sunlight of 100 mW·cm−2, as shown Fig. S5, the dispersion of 1% mass fraction is suitable for studying the PCE of ZNC-550 and ZNCs. Therefore, the heating and cooling curves of 1% mass fraction of ZNC-550 and ZNCs dispersion were measured, as shown in Fig. 5(b), it can be seen that the temperature of water is only increased 8.1 ℃ after 2 hours of light exposure. However, the temperatures of the dispersions of ZNC-550, ZNC-700, ZNC-800, ZNC-900 and ZNC-1000 are increased 10.5, 11.5, 12, 12.4 and 12.8 ℃, respectively, which means that the achievable maximum temperatures of dispersion have been greatly increased after adding the ZNC-550 and ZNCs. This is because the dispersed ZNC-550 and ZNCs generate heat when light irradiated, and the heat is transmitted to the entire system which increase the temperature of system. Meanwhile, the PCE of ZNC-550 and ZNCs was calculated in order to evaluate the photothermal conversion performance more intuitively and clearly, and the calculation formulas and methods are described in supporting information. The pivotal B value was calculated according to the cooling stage, and its numerical value is related to the nature of the dispersion and the device, and the influence of dispersed phase is negligible. In this paper, the B value was calculated by ZNC-800 dispersion with 1% mass fraction as an example, as shown in Fig. 5(c). The value within 600–2400 s of the cooling stage was selected to make B value more accurate. The slope of the obtained line is -B, and the calculation result is B = 7.6 × 10-4 S-1. As shown in Fig. 5(d), in the dispersion with 1% mass fraction, the PCE of ZNC-550, ZNC-700, ZNC-800, ZNC-900, and ZNC-1000 are 31.6%, 44.7%, 56.5%, 51.3% and 61.8%, respectively. The PCE is consistent with the absorption spectrum of ZNC-550 and ZNCs in the UV–Vis-NIR, which indicates that the absorption of light is an important step to realize photothermal conversion. 3.3 Characterization of photocatalytic performance In order to verify the photothermally-driven catalytic performance of ZNC-550 and ZNCs, propylene oxide (PO) was chosen to conduct catalytic experiments. Table 2 shows the effect of ZNC-550, ZNCs and different reaction conditions on the yield of propylene carbonate (PC). The catalytic efficiency of ZNC-550 is not satisfactory, due to its lower Zn (0.68%) content and smaller specific surface area (14.71 m2·g−1), caused the yield of PC is only 46.1% (Table 2, entry 1). The catalytic performance of ZNCs first increased and then decreased. Among them, ZNC-800 has the best catalytic efficiency, and the yield of PC reached 79.6% (Table 2, entries 2–5). The reason for this result is that g-C3N4 was pyrolyzed during the calcination process, and the gradually released porous carbon nanosheets have high specific surface area (315.91 m2·g−1) and the highest Zn atoms content (1.13%), which promote CO2 cycloaddition with PO. However, at 900 °C or higher, part of Zn atoms are carbothermal reduced and then evaporated, and resulting in the decrease of catalytic efficiency. In order to further verify the catalytic effect of Zn atoms and N atoms as Lewis acid and Lewis base sites, respectively, AC as nitrogen-free carbon materials and NC-800 were used as control experiments for catalysis. The NC-800 and AC catalyzed the CO2 cycloaddition with epoxide under the same reaction conditions of ZNC-800, the yield of PC is only 46.7% and 35.1%, respectively (Table 2, entries 6–7). Moreover, the yield of PC is 21.8% and 33.6% without co-catalyst or catalyst, respectively (Table 2, entries 8 and 9). In conclusion, there are synergistic effects among Zn atoms, N atoms and co-catalyst in the cycloaddition of CO2 [70-72]. Subsequently, a series of contrast experiments to further investigate the effect of reaction conditions on the yield of PC. The yield of PC reached 94.3% and 90.4% with the mass of ZNC-800 increasing to 60 mg, or the pressure increasing to 0.4 MPa, respectively (Table 2, entries 10 and 11). Notably, there is a few yields of PC in the absence of light (Table 2, entry 12), because the entire catalytic system has no energy input and the CO2 cycloaddition cannot be driven. When the light intensity simulate sunlight (100 mW·cm−2) (Table 2, entry 13), the yield of PC reached 51.7% after 24 h. When full-spectrum light was replaced by visible light, the yield of PC is only 50.2% after 10 h (Table 2, entry 14), because the total energy input of the catalytic system is reduced when near-infrared light and ultraviolet light are filtered out, it resulted that the decrease of the catalytic efficiency [73]. It is worth mentioning that compared with photocatalytic technology and photoelectric conversion technology, photothermal conversion technology is not only relatively easy and low-cost, but also can achieve full spectrum utilization, and has great application potential in the efficient use of solar energy. The light intensity is an important factor in the catalytic reaction of photothermally-driven, hence, the influence of light intensity on the yield of PC was studied, and the results are showed in Fig. 6 (a). The yields of PC are increased from 37.7% to 93.3% when the light intensities were increased from 600 mW·cm−2 to 1200 mW·cm−2, correspondingly. The equilibrium temperature of CO2 cycloaddition under different light intensities were recorded to further explore the reasons how the light intensity affects the reaction. It can be seen that the equilibrium temperatures have been increased from 55 ℃ to 96 ℃. The results proved that CO2 cycloaddition is essentially effected by equilibrium temperature, with the light intensity increasing [74]. The effect of reaction time on the catalytic performance of CO2 cycloaddition is shown in Fig. 6(b). The reaction time were increased from 2 h to 12 h, and the yield of PC are increased from 11.8% to 91.1%. Detailed analysis shows that the yield of PC increased rapidly in the initial 6 h, and the yield of PC increased slowly in the subsequent 6 h of the cycloaddition. The photothermal curve of the temperature of the CO2 cycloaddition process is recorded, and the entire reaction system basically reached the equilibrium temperature at 6 h. Both the continuous increase of temperature and the extension of reaction time are the main factors for the increase of PC yield in the initial 6 h. In the subsequent 6 h, the equilibrium temperature of the cycloaddition is basically reached, therefore, the reaction time becomes the main factor affects the yield of PC. In order to further explore the difference and connection between light heating and traditional electric heating CO2 cycloaddition, the equilibrium temperature of the light heating was set as the highest temperature of electric heating, and other reaction conditions remain the same. The real-time temperatures of light heating and electric heating were recorded, and the result is showed in Fig. 7 . The figure shows that electric heating has a faster heating rate, and can basically reach the equilibrium temperature in 3 h, while light heating takes 6 h. In addition, the results show that the yield of PC is 80.6% in the case of electric heating, which is lower than 91.1% of light heating. The reason for the higher efficiency of light heating is may that the catalyst of ZNC-800 is heated in situ by light, and heat diffuses into the reaction system after generating. The surface temperature of ZNC-800 under the light intensity of 1000 mW·cm−2 was tested to prove this result. ZNC-800 was placed on white paper, and two measuring points were selected for temperature testing: one point measures the temperature of ZNC-800, the other point measures the temperature of the blank white paper (Fig. S6). The results showed that the surface temperature of ZNC-800 is much higher than the temperature of the reaction system under light heating. Moreover, catalytic reaction is occurred on the surface of catalyst, therefore, the CO2 cycloaddition is promoted. 3.4 Adaptability and recyclability of catalyst The adaptability of ZNC-800 in the cycloaddition of CO2 with different epoxide was investigated, and the results are showed in Table 3 . ZNC-800 has the best catalytic effect on epichlorohydrin, and the yield of corresponding carbonate reached 88.4% in 10 h (Table 3, entry 1). This may be because the end substituents of 3-chloropropylene oxide partly fall off to form Cl-, which can act as a nucleophiles to promote the ring opening of epoxide [75]. ZNC-800 has a certain catalytic activity for epoxide that contains other end groups. Besides, the yields of cyclic carbonates that correspond to different epoxides can be reached more than 80% by extending reaction time to 20 h (Table 3, entries 2–5). However, ZNC-800 has no catalytic activity for cyclohexene oxide because of its high steric hindrance and inherent inertness [76,77] (Table 3, entry 7). The recyclability of catalysts is very important for reducing production costs. Considering this problem, the reusability of ZNC-800 was investigated. ZNC-800 was recovered by filtration and rinsed by ethanol after each cycloaddition. It can be seen from Fig. 8 that the yield of PC is still more than 80% after 5 consecutive cycles, which indicated that ZNC-800 has a relatively good reusability. The Zn content in ZNC-800 and PC were determined by ICP-MS after the fifth cycles. The results show that the Zn content in ZNC-800 and PC were 1.04% and 0.005%, respectively. The leached Zn content in PC is race and the total leaching ratio of only 8 % is satisfactory. 3.5 Comparison of catalytic performance ZNC-800 was compared with other Zn-N-C system catalysts (Table 4 ). It can be seen that the CO2 cycloaddition is generally carried out under traditional heating, also with higher temperature and pressure, or longer reaction time (Table 4, entries 1–6). However, the CO2 cycloaddition is carried out under mild conditions, it will take a long time for the cyclic carbonate to reach a certain yield (Table 4, entry 7). The method of photothermally-driven CO2 cycloaddition was adopted by Yang et al., and the yield of cyclic carbonate reached 94% in the case of fewer reactants and using solvents (Table 4, entry 8). The yield of cyclic carbonate was further improved by Guo et al. under the condition of solvent-free and increased reactants (Table 4, entry 9). In this work, compared with Guo et al., the yield of PC still reached 93.3%, under the condition that the amount of catalyst and co-catalyst were reduced by two-thirds and by one-half, respectively. 3.6 Mechanism of the CO2 cycloaddition Collectively, ZNCs exhibit satisfactory photothermally-driven catalytic activity through the investigation of structural morphology and catalytic performance, which is attributed to the large specific surface area, abundant Lewis acid-base active sites and excellent photothermal conversion performance of ZNCs. Therefore, on the basis of previous research results [29,76], the possible mechanism of CO2 cycloaddition catalyzed by ZNCs under photothermally-driven is proposed (Fig. 9 ). Firstly, epoxide and CO2 are respectively adsorbed and activated by Zn atoms as a Lewis acidic site and N atoms as a Lewis basic site. Secondly, Br- of TBAB acts as a nucleophile to attack the C atoms of β-C-O bond with small steric hindrance of epoxide to ring opening, and form β-C-Br intermediate with oxygen anion. Thirdly, the oxygen anion in the intermediate reacts with the C atoms of CO2 that activated by N, and CO2 is inserted to form alkyl carbonate intermediate. Fourthly, the alkyl carbonate intermediate undergoes the intramolecular ring-closure reaction, and the nucleophilic group Br- is separated simultaneously. Finally, cyclic carbonate is generated, meanwhile, the catalyst is regenerated. Notably, the ZNCs provide energy for CO2 cycloaddition through photothermal effect during the entire reaction process. 4 Conclusions In summary, a simple one-step pyrolysis method, using glucose as a carbon source, zinc nitrate hexahydrate as a Zn source, melamine as a N source and sacrificial template, was utilized to synthesize ZNCs. The resultant, ZNC-800 has a graphene-like layered structure, uniformly distributed Zn and N atoms, high surface area (315.91 m2·g−1), large average pore diameter (16.1 nm), large pore volume (1.271 cm3·g−1), full spectrum absorption and high photothermal conversion efficiency (51.3%). The photothermal effect and the synergistic effect of Lewis acid-base catalytic sites enable the yield of PC to reach 91.1%. In addition, the catalytic efficiency of ZNC-800 is not significantly reduced after 5 times recycles and has good adaptability to different epoxides. Moreover, ZNC-800 has a higher catalytic efficiency than those prepared by traditional heating methods because it can be quickly in-situ heated by light. More importantly, light energy is an infinite clean energy. Converting CO2 through the photothermal effect is in line with the principles of green chemistry and sustainable development. This work not only provides a simple photothermally-driven CO2 cycloaddition strategy, but also explaines how the photothermal effect affects the catalytic efficiency. The result provides a certain reference for the general photothermally-driven catalytic reaction in catalyst design and energy conversion. coredata.dc:description: Solar energy is considered as the cleanest, cheapest, and most sustainable energy source, and CO2 cycloaddition that is drove by solar energy has unique advantages in the aspect of energy and environmental. Therefore, Zn and N co-doped porous carbon nanosheets (ZNCs), which were synthesized by a simple one-step pyrolysis method, as catalysts and photothermal material to photothermally drive cycloaddition of CO2. The prepared ZNCs show graphene-like layered structure, uniformly distributed Lewis acid (Zn atoms) sites and Lewis base (N atoms) sites, full spectrum absorption and high photothermal conversion efficiency. More importantly, ZNCs have a higher catalytic efficiency than traditional heating methods because it can be quickly in-situ heated by light, hence the yield of cyclic carbonate reached 91.1% (0.1 MPa CO2, 1000 mW·cm−2 full-spectrum irradiation, 12 h). ZNCs were recycled five times without significant reduction in catalytic efficiency, and have high activity to other series of epoxides. A possible CO2 cycloaddition mechanism which is catalyzed by ZNCs is proposed, including the step of adsorption, ring opening, insertion and cyclic carbonates formation.
coredata.dc:title: Zn and N co-doped porous carbon nanosheets for photothermally-driven CO2 cycloaddition
